Award.AwardTitle: Preparing Carbon-Rich and All-Carbon Materials Via Self-Assembly
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program supports Professor Nancy Goroff of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, to prepare novel conjugated polymers and graphitic structures for optoelectronic applications. The focus of this work is to create new high-carbon or all-carbon materials with unusual structures that impart unique and desirable physical, chemical, and electronic properties. Careful characterization determines the molecular and supramolecular structure for each, and through collaborations with analytical and physical chemists, the electronic and optical properties and possible applications for these materials are explored. The research involves the use of poly(diiododiacetylene) as a precursor to ordered high-carbon materials, including the linear carbon allotrope carbyne. Also, the preparation of new ordered polymers from other diynes, triynes, and tetraynes. Poly(dibromodiacetylene) is a primary target for a highly planar conjugated polymer with a broader absorption spectrum and greater photostability than poly(diiododiacetylene), and as a precursor to other materials via post-polymerization modification.

This research provides methods for preparing new carbon-based semiconducting materials. One application for these materials is in thin-film solar cells. A key goal is to find new carbon-based semi-conductors that can absorb a greater percentage of the visible and infrared solar spectrum, increasing the efficiency of the resulting solar cell. These materials can also be prepared completely free of toxic metal contaminants such as palladium or zinc. New materials are critical to the development of the important field of optoelectronics. A major component of the work involves collaborative research, which brings together scientists with different expertise and research focus, increasing communication across disciplinary boundaries. Graduate students and undergraduates gain experience in making new materials and studying their properties, skills that can be used in industries as varied as pharmaceuticals and electronics. Professor Goroff is deeply involved in outreach activities, notably through the Alan Alda Center for Communicating Science, housed in the School of Journalism at Stony Brook. She serves on the Steering Committee for the Alda Center, and acts as a judge for the Center's annual Flame Challenge, a competition that has attracted international attention and led to significant insights about how to communicate scientific ideas most effectively to children.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to make novel carbon-rich materials with unusual structures that impart unique and desirable properties, both for applications such as solar energy and light-emitting diodes and to answer fundamental questions about how such materials behave. In a previous project, also funded by the National Science Foundation, we developed a solid-state reaction to make poly(diiododiacetylene) (PIDA), a highly ordered polymer containing only carbon and iodine. In this project, we studied the chemical behavior and properties of PIDA, used similar methods to prepare other new polymers, and characterized the properties of those new materials, as well.

PIDA is a shiny metallic-looking material, even though it has no metals in it, and previous experiments had indicated it is a semi-conductor. As part of this project, we collaborated with researchers at Brookhaven National Lab to measure the electron mobility in PIDA, and found that it does carry current, but is an order of magnitude less conductive than some well known semi-conducting polymers, such as poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT).

Because of its simple structure and high carbon content, PIDA is also interesting as a precursor to the hypothetical linear allotrope of carbon, carbyne. In this project, we investigated many different sets of conditions for removing the iodine from PIDA. The challenge we found was that the polymer PIDA tends to aggregate into bundles, and removing the iodine from the center of the bundle requires high temperature, which then leads to other reactions, ultimately giving graphite-like carbon instead of the desired linear carbyne. Thus, to make carbyne from PIDA, we needed to change the way that PIDA is prepared, so that we can prevent the formation of the polymer bundles. In this funding period, we have made progress in developing a new "polyrotaxane" synthesis for PIDA, and will continue to work on that synthesis, so that we can use PIDA to make carbyne.

In addition to our studies of PIDA, we targeted and prepared several other new polymers using similar methods. PIDA is the polymer of diiodobutadiyne (C4I2). In this funding period, we successfully synthesized the related polymer from dibromobutadiyne (C4Br2), poly(dibromodiacetylene) (PBDA), and from diiodohexatriyne (C6I2), poly(iodoethynyliododiacetylene) (PIEDA). PBDA is much more stable than PIDA, but still not soluble enough to make thin films with high bulk conductivity. PIEDA is less stable than PIDA, though we do not know yet what reactions are leading to that instability.

In addition to using dibromobutadiyne and diiodohexatriyne as precursors to polymers, we pursued the polymerization of many other small diyne molecules. The most interesting results came from precursors containing two diynes, connected by a linker. The product "ladder polymers" from these starting materials should have smaller electronic band gaps. We succeeded in preparing crystals of the starting precursors, and obtained evidence that they reacted in the solid state to form the desired polymers. However, the resulting polymeric material was very unstable, exploding even while still in the crystal. This observation was unexpected, and important for understanding the chemistry of carbon-rich materials.

Overall, we prepared several new carbon-rich polymers, studied the structure and properties of the materials we made, and made small-molecule starting materials for additional new polymers. The results of this research have been presented at many international scientific meetings and have been reported in several publications, with more publications in preparation now. Seven graduate students and several undergraduates received training in chemistry research through their work on this project, including students who have gone on into industry positions and students who have become faculty members at other institutions.
